_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

Pregis, LLC (Pregis) is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of Isobutane is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Pregis is a specialty foam manufacturing facility, which produces polyethylene (PE) foam and is located at 1867 South Veterans Blvd. in Tupelo, Mississippi. 



The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to processes storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is Isobutane, which is used as a blowing agent in the manufacturing process and is stored in excess of the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.



Polyethylene foam or "PE" foam is a plastic product made of polyethylene resin that is mixed with reclaimed product and additives.  Processes include the extrusion of the mixed resin through a highly specialized extruder; adding a liquid blowing agent (Isobutane), then cooling the material and forcing it through a die. The finished product is produced in variety of colors, thicknesses, and densities. The Isobutane is stored in three (3) storage tanks located in the tank farm.  The Isobutane Storage Tanks include one (1) 7,000) gallon and two (2) 6,000-gallon storage tanks with a combined maximum storage capacity of 19,000 gallons. The facility maintains administrative controls that allow the tanks to be filled to 80% of capacity which equates to 15,200 gallons or 71,288 pounds of Isobutane.



The entire facility is con

sidered one process, and based on applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 3 of the RMP regulations.



C. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Process Safety Information: Pregis will complete a compilation of written safety information to be used in conducting the process hazard analysis (PHA). The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane System. The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane system.



Process Hazard Analysis: Pregis will update and revalidate the PHA as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The PHA was conducted using the "What If" methodology, which is one of the methodologies specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including one member who has expertise in the Isobutane system and a member knowledgeable in the specified PHA methodology. A system was established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operation, maintenance and other employees who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. The PHA was updated and revalidated on April 27 and 28, 2021.



Operating Procedures: Pregis has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where Isobutane is utilized. These written operating procedures will be consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures will be rea

dily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the Isobutane system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. Pregis will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate. Pregis will develop and implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the Pregis facility.



Training: Pregis will provide training for each employee associated with the Isobutane system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.67. Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. Pregis documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.



Mechanical Integrity: Pregis will develop a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the Isobutane system (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.

Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the Isobutane system components receives training at least every three (3) years or more often if necessary.



Management of Change: Pregis will establish and implement written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures; and, changes to Pregis that effect the Isobutane system. These procedures assure that appropriate considerations are addressed prior to any change. Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are informed of, and trained in, the change prior to startup of the system. If a change results in the change in the process safety informatio

n, operation procedures, or practices, they will be updated accordingly.



Pre-Startup Safety Review: Pregis will perform a Pre-Startup Safety Review according to 40 CFR 68.67 when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information, equipment, operating procedures or practices.



Compliance Audits: Pregis will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least knowledgeable in the Isobutane system. A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. Pregis will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained. A compliance audit was last conducted on July 21, 2019.



Incident Investigation: Pregis will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Isobutane. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and Pregis will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented. Incident investigation reports will be retained for five (5) years.



Employee Participation: Pregis will develop a written plan of action regarding employee participation. The facility will consult with employees on the conduct and development of process hazard analysis and other elements of the system management. Pregis will provide employee access to hazard analysis and to all other information required to be devel

oped under 40 CFR Part 68.



Hot Work Permit: Pregis will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the Isobutane system.



Contractors: When selecting a contractor, Pregis will obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract owner or operator's safety performance and programs. Pregis will inform the contract owner or operator of the known release hazards related to the contractor's work and the Isobutane system. Pregis will explain to the contract owner or operator of, the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan. Pregis will periodically evaluate the performance of the contract owner or operator in fulfilling their obligations as specified below. Contract owners or operators will assure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform their job. Contract owners or operators and Pregis will assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential release hazard related to their job and the Isobutane system and the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.



D. Five-year Accident History

Pregis has not had an accidental release of Isobutane that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or any known off-site, death, injuries evacuations, sheltering in place, property, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five (5) years. 



E. Emergency Response Program

Pregis has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. This program includes the following elements: 

1. An emergency response plan, which is maintained on site and contains at least the following elements:

a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;

b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to accidental human exposures; 

c. Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of Isobutane;

2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection;

3. Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and

4. Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at Pregis and ensure that employees are informed of changes.



F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In an attempt to insure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training concerning this safety and environmental program and others will be conducted annually. This program requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the Isobutane system. Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires Pregis to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.
